title: Holy shit, ANOTHER ryze rework? For fucks sake... that will make 4 so far.
body:
fix it this time please.

whatever it is about him that causes him to be broken, and suck rework resources into himself like some kind of super massive black hole

Fucking.
Fix.
It.

Don't try to make him the "next experiment" or "potentially super cool". Just fucking fix it. We don't care if his passive is ultra unique or if his itemization is special. We want a champion that doesn't require constant maintenance; other champions need attention and failed Ryze reworks keep them from being looked at.
Fix it bro. Fix it.

replies.body: {{champion:72}} Worry not, I shall join you soon enough.

It makes me mad that pre-Juggernaut-update Skarner was fine but they had to change it because they can't understand that some champions will never be popular [excluding when they are OP, of course], and that is fine.
{{champion:83}}  What did you say about not being popular?
You're in the wrong game. Go back to shovel knight.

But that's not okay. Every champion should have a reason to be picked, in fact every champion should have a situation where they are the best option for a pick. That is why they are reworking Brand and Vel'koz, they are balanced but don't actually have good niches. 

Not that the skarner rework was a success, i agree it wasn't, but it was justified. I don't think he was very high priority on their list, probably just figured if they were doing Darius and Morde they would get in Skarner as well. Imo Skarner needs the rework more than Ryze does, right now Ryze is only balanced at the highest level of play. 

Skarner should be the juggernaut of the jungle, but it is very hard to gank without a gap closer and a juggernaut with a gap closer is pretty broken. Imo i have no idea why they took away his permaslow, that was entirely balanced to have on a juggernaut. A jugg should be "Get in range of me, and you suffer for it". Tahm Kench and Darius are probably the best examples of that right now.
ok then, son, you gotta learn something, tahm and skarner are too mobile to be considered juggernauts.
tahm has ult, but no ability to move himself beyond that. Tahm's problem is the juggernauts "get in range of me and suffer" ideal is kinda fucked up on him because his Q gives him a huge range

Lack of popularity isn't always due to lack of a reason to pick them. Some champions even when they offer something others don't and do really well still won't have much if a pick rate simply because they don't look or feel appealing. Some champions had their visuals altered and minor changes just so they look appealing in hopes they would be picked more. Although, there's over 100 champs and expecting them all to be played equally is just a dream that won't ever happen. As long as there are people that enjoy a champion it should be fine, there's no reason to change champions purely for popularity as that usually doesn't work out well and usually means taking popularity from another champion anyways.
Excellent example of this is Gallio, he's not popular not because he's not balanced, but because his niche (punishing teams who are way too magic damage heavy) is not something that happens often.
Yea I started to play him before the rework. I carried really hard in games but after the rework he was just some broken monster who got gutted.{{item:3070}} {{champion:72}} {{item:3070}}
The perma root bullshit is what makes him broken. He shouldn't gain a huge MS buff and just chase you down the lane to perma CC you and 100-0 you with just a {{item:3070}} {{item:3010}}
it really sucks that u can beat him early and suddenly he outscales u with just two mana giving items

Is Mana even his primary damage stat anymore? I tried to pick Ryze back up during his free week and his ratios for AP were stronger than his mana ratios. Mana looked like a secondary stat, not the main stat it used to be on him.

I might have misread the tooltips but he looked like he needed AP more than he used to back in the day.

Yeah, but Seraph's + RoA are some of the highest AP you can get from two items thanks to their recent buffs, and you tend to have more mana than AP anyway, so the lower scaling probably just reflects that.

Plus he gets a lot of CDR from his ult passive so he doesn't want mana regen since those items give CDR, so he inevitably goes for mana AP items which give him durability to let him tank damage more with his short range.

Salty Ryze main downvoted you. But we all know that this a major complaint on Ryze. Riot wants counterplay, and that perma-root is the antithesis of that. This problem is tantamount to the counterplay Annie has, not being able to even farm if the cc ability/passive is ready. Now, Ryze should be able to have huge burst, but massively powerful CC is a problem when it's on the same champion as well.
Where is the rework?

Ryze is a Mage/Tank hybrid with a mostly point and click kit. That's your problem, anytime he is even remotely strong any idiot that can role their face across a keyboard will find success with him.

But right now he's extremely strong, the problem is that only the very best Ryze players can actually use him well enough to succeed with him.

His problem right now is actually the exact opposite of what it was in the past - he's so hard to play correctly that if any non-pro can ever do well with him then he's probably incredibly broken.

Ryze is strong right now for people that play him alot, not for face roll idiots. Nothing wrong with that, Azir has had the same pattern since his release. If this is a balance problem then I'm for one fine with it, for a champ that who has been face roll for most of his existence I'm glad that now I only run the risk of loosing to a Ryze if its someone who plays him alot. 

I don't see why every one seems to think we should be going back wards with him when his past iterations is what prompted 4 reworks in the first place.

Characters are designed to be used by people for fun, at the end of the day. They need skill curves, because getting better at champions is fun and rewarding, but if a champion requires 100 miserable games of failure before you can actually have any fun with them then that is just too extreme, particularly when champions like that (i.e. just Azir and Ryze) tend to be basically impossible to lose with when you have mastered them. Riot doesn't want "I've learned this champion" to mean "I cannot lose with this champion", no matter how hard they are to play.
At least you aren't {{champion:266}} , who Riot released and was almost immediately like: "What the hell did we just release."

It's not just {{champion:266}}  Riot has yet to get a melee AA based carry right.. {{champion:11}} {{champion:157}} {{champion:23}}  are all pretty frustrating to play against when they are strong.

Although in their defense idk what a healthy AA melee carry would look like... Squishy but in melee range means death so they need some way to survive but it is bound to be frustrating to play against.

Not to mention the fact that every single time they try to make a true melee ADC it just ends up basically becoming an assassin/fighter hybrd that uses auto attacks instead of spells. Yasuo was supposed to basically weave in and out of combat doing DPS in a pattern somewhat like ranged ADCs.
I hate to be that guy, because League is my main game, but DotA melee carries are relatively healthy.
